entry.et: Middle English, from Old English rōwan; akin to Middle High German rüejen to row, Latin remus oar

def.dt: :to propel a boat by means of oars
:to move by or as if by the propulsion of oars
:to propel with or as if with oars
:to participate in (a rowing match)
:to compete against in rowing
:to pull (an oar) in a crew
:to transport in an oar-propelled boat
:an act or instance of rowing

entry.et: Middle English rawe; akin to Old English rǣw row, Old High German rīga line, and perhaps to Sanskrit rikhati he scratches

def.dt: :a number of objects arranged in a usually straight line a row of bottles
:the line along which such objects are arranged planted the corn in parallel rows
:way street
:a street or area dominated by a specific kind of enterprise or occupancy doctors' row
:twelve-tone row
:a continuous strip usually running horizontally or parallel to a baseline
:a horizontal arrangement of items
:one after another :successively
:to form into rows
:a noisy disturbance or quarrel
:to engage in a row :have a quarrel
:one of a series of houses connected by common sidewalls and forming a continuous group
:a prison area housing inmates sentenced to death usually used with on prisoners waiting on death row
:a district of cheap saloons and flophouses frequented by vagrants and alcoholics
:the chosen sequence of tones that serves as the basis for a work of serial music
:twelve-tone row
